WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A STUDY TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HEAT AND FRESH WATER EXCHANGE IN THE SPURS-2 REGION THROUGH DIRECT ESTIMATES OF THE HEAT, MOISTURE, AND MOMENTUM FLUXES, THEIR RELATED MEAN VARIABLES, AND PRECIPITATION. THE SALINITY VARIABILITY OF THE UPPER OCEAN IS PROFOUNDLY INFLUENCED BY THE FRESHWATER FLUX AT THE SURFACE, IN COMBINATION WITH THE EFFECTS OF MIXING AND ADVECTION WITHIN THE UPPER OCEAN. THE MIXING IN THE UPPER OCEAN IS ITSELF AFFECTED BY THE SURFACE FLUXES OF FRESHWATER, MOMENTUM, AND HEAT. THUS, IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE PRECIPITATION EVENTS THAT OCCUR AT CLOUD SCALES THROUGH TO THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BALANCE AND THEN TO THE LARGER TIME- AND SPACE-SCALES, IT IS NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY MEASURE THESE FLUXES. A PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO PROVIDE MEASUREMENTS FROM SHIP DEPLOYMENTS DURING THE SPURS-2 EXPERIMENT IN THE TROPICAL EASTERN PACIFIC OCEAN THAT CAN BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER ON-BOARD MEASUREMENTS SUCH AS SURFACE AND PROFILE TEMPERATURE, SALINITY, CURRENT, AND OCEAN MIXING OBSERVATIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE A FULL PICTURE OF THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE SURFACE FORCING AND THE RESULTING UPPER OCEAN STRUCTURE. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE USE OF INSTRUMENTS TO MEASURE THE TURBULENT FLUXES OF HEAT, MOISTURE, AND MOMENTUM, IN ADDITION TO PRECIPITATION AND RADIATION FLUXES. THE PRINCIPLE HYPOTHESIS OF THIS RESEARCH IS THAT THE SURFACE FLUXES ARE A KEY FACTOR IN THE EVOLUTION OF SALINITY VARIABILITY IN THIS REGION, AND THAT MEASUREMENTS OF THESE PARAMETERS WILL GREATLY ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO SIMULATE AND PREDICT THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BUDGET AND RESULTING SALINITY STRUCTURE IN THIS REGION.

THE SALINITY VARIABILITY OF THE UPPER OCEAN IS PROFOUNDLY INFLUENCED BY THE FRESHWATER FLUX AT THE SURFACE, IN COMBINATION WITH THE EFFECTS OF MIXING AND ADVECTION WITHIN THE UPPER OCEAN. THE MIXING IN THE UPPER OCEAN IS ITSELF AFFECTED BY THE SURFACE FLUXES OF FRESHWATER, MOMENTUM, AND HEAT. THUS, IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE PRECIPITATION EVENTS THAT OCCUR AT CLOUD SCALES THROUGH TO THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BALANCE AND THEN TO THE LARGER TIME- AND SPACE-SCALES, IT IS NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY MEASURE THESE FLUXES. A PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO PROVIDE MEASUREMENTS FROM SHIP DEPLOYMENTS DURING THE SPURS-2 EXPERIMENT IN THE TROPICAL EASTERN PACIFIC OCEAN THAT CAN BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER ON-BOARD MEASUREMENTS SUCH AS SURFACE AND PROFILE TEMPERATURE, SALINITY, CURRENT, AND OCEAN MIXING OBSERVATIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE A FULL PICTURE OF THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE SURFACE FORCING AND THE RESULTING UPPER OCEAN STRUCTURE. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE USE OF INSTRUMENTS TO MEASURE THE TURBULENT FLUXES OF HEAT, MOISTURE, AND MOMENTUM, IN ADDITION TO PRECIPITATION AND RADIATION FLUXES. THE PRINCIPLE HYPOTHESIS OF THIS RESEARCH IS THAT THE SURFACE FLUXES ARE A KEY FACTOR IN THE EVOLUTION OF SALINITY VARIABILITY IN THIS REGION, AND THAT MEASUREMENTS OF THESE PARAMETERS WILL GREATLY ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO SIMULATE AND PREDICT THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BUDGET AND RESULTING SALINITY STRUCTURE IN THIS REGION.

doc.ContractDescription: DENDRITIC MICROSTRUCTURES FORMED DURING CASTING, WELDING, AND BRAZING DETERMINE THE PROPERTIES OF COMMERCIAL METALLIC ALLOYS PRODUCED IN NUMEROUS INDUSTRIES, WITH APPLICATIONS RANGING FROM AUTOMOBILE ENGINE PARTS TO AIRCRAFT TURBINE BLADES. MICROGRAVITY EXPERIMENTS PROVIDE A UNIQUE MEANS TO INVESTIGATE MICROSTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT UNDER WELL CONTROLLED CONDITIONS IN A PURELY DIFFUSIVE GROWTH REGIME WITH NEGLIGIBLE CONVECTION IN THE MELT. THIS PROJECT MAKES USE OF STATE OF THE ART NUMERICAL MODELS TO ESTABLISH BENCHMARK COMPARISONS BETWEEN THEORETICAL PREDICTIONS AND MICROGRAVITY EXPERIMENTS CARRIED OUT ABOARD THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION ISS AND SOUNDING ROCKETS. THIS RESEARCH HAS FOR OBJECTIVES TO DERIVE FROM THOSE COMPARISONS FUNDAMENTAL INSIGHTS INTO MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION AND TO ENHANCE THE PREDICTIVE CAPABILITIES OF COMPUTATIONAL MODELING. THE CONTINUATION OF THIS PROJECT OVER THE NEXT 3 YEARS WILL MERGE TWO ONGOING COMPUTATIONAL MODELING EFFORTS. THE FIRST EFFORT FOCUSES ON MODELING DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION EXPERIMENTS IN METALLIC AND CONCENTRATED TRANSPARENT ORGANIC ALLOYS IN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ESA NASA CETSOL 5 PROJECT CARRIED OUT IN COLLABORATION WITH US AND EUROPEAN PARTNERS. THE GENERAL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF COMPLEX PHYSICAL PHENOMENA GOVERNING THE COLUMNAR TO EQUIAXED TRANSITION CET IN ALLOY SOLIDIFICATION AND ITS CONSEQUENCES FOR INDUSTRIAL CASTINGS. THIS PART OF THE RESEARCH BUILDS DIRECTLY ON PROGRESS ACCOMPLISHED DURING THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE CURRENT GRANT. THE SECOND EFFORT FOCUSES ON MODELING DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION EXPERIMENTS IN THE DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION INSERT DSI OF THE DECLIC FACILITY DEVICE FOR THE STUDY OF CRITICAL LIQUIDS AND CRYSTALLIZATION ONBOARD THE ISS AS PART OF A CNES NASA PROJECT. THOSE EXPERIMENTS VISUALIZE FOR THE FIRST TIME IN DILUTE TRANSPARENT ALLOYS THE SOLID LIQUID INTERFACE EVOLUTION IN THREE DIMENSIONS UNDER DIFFUSIVE GROWTH CONDITIONS. THEY PROVIDE A WEALTH OF NEW OBSERVATIONS TO ELUCIDATE COMPLEX MECHANISMS GOVERNING THE SPATIOTEMPORAL EVOLUTION OF THREE DIMENSIONAL DENDRITIC ARRAY STRUCTURES. THIS PART OF THE RESEARCH BUILDS ON MAJOR PROGRESS ACHIEVED TO DATE IN THE SPADES PROJECT CARRIED OUT IN COLLABORATION WITH COLLABORATORS. BOTH PROJECTS INVESTIGATE BASIC ASPECTS OF DENDRITIC MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION AND ARE HIGHLY SYNERGISTIC. SYNERGISM HAS BEEN INCREASED BY THE ADDITION IN THE CETSOL 5 PROJECT OF STUDIES OF THE TRANSPARENT ALLOY SYSTEM NEOPENTYLGLYCOL D CAMPHOR NPG DC. THIS SYSTEM ADDS THE CAPABILITY TO VISUALIZE BOTH COLUMNAR AND EQUIAXED DENDRITIC GRAIN DEVELOPMENT AND THE CET IN A CONCENTRATED ALLOY REGIME, THEREBY COMPLEMENTING THE DECLIC DSI STUDIES OF COLUMNAR DENDRITES IN DILUTE SCN CAMPHOR ALLOYS. SYNERGISM BETWEEN THOSE PROJECTS ALSO STEMS FROM THE FACT THAT BASIC INSIGHTS INTO DENDRITE MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION OBTAINED IN THE DECLIC DSI STUDIES ARE DIRECTLY RELEVANT TO UNDERSTANDING AND MODELING THE COLUMNAR TO EQUIAXED TRANSITION.

doc.ContractDescription: ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT PROPERTIES OF MESOSCALE EDDIES IS THEIR ABILITY TO TRANSPORT SUCH DYNAMICALLY AND CLIMATICALLY IMPORTANT OCEANIC TRACERS, AS HEAT, SALT AND CARBON. RECENT STUDIES SUGGEST THAT THIS EDDY INDUCED TRANSPORT HAS COMPLEX NON-UNIFORM SPATIAL STRUCTURE AND IS OFTEN HIGHLY ANISOTROPIC. THE EDDY-INDUCED TRACER TRANSPORT IS PARAMETERIZED BY EDDY DIFFUSIVITY IN NON-EDDYRESOLVING CLIMATE MODELS, BUT THESE PARAMETERIZATIONS ARE OFTEN PURELY EMPIRICAL AND DO NOT ACCOUNT FOR THE OBSERVED COMPLEXITY OF THE EDDY FIELD. ON THE OTHER HAND, EMERGING HIGH RESOLUTION MODELS PARTLY RESOLVE THE MESOSCALE, BUT THE ACCURACY OF THEIR SIMULATION OF THE MOST IMPORTANT EDDY TRANSPORT PROPERTIES REQUIRES VERIFICATION. RELIABLE ESTIMATES OF THE EDDY INDUCED TRANSPORT ARE URGENTLY NEEDED FOR ADVANCING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF OCEAN AND CLIMATE DYNAMICS. SATELLITE ALTIMETRY BOTH THE CURRENT AND FUTURE SWOT MISSIONS PROVIDES THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WITH THE NEARLY GLOBAL NEARSURFACE GEOSTROPHIC VELOCITY ESTIMATES. USING SYNTHETIC LAGRANGIAN PARTICLE TRAJECTORIES, SIMULATED USING THESE ALTIMETRIC VELOCITIES, ONE CAN READILY DERIVE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES. HOWEVER, THE RELIABILITY AND INTERPRETATION OF THE RESULTING EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES PRESENTS A CHALLENGE BECAUSE OF THE LIMITED SPATIO TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, THE NON UNIFORM SPATIAL COVERAGE, AND THE ABSENCE OF NON-GEOSTROPHIC VELOCITY COMPONENTS IN ALTIMETRY DERIVED CURRENTS. WE PROPOSE TO UNDERTAKE A MULTI YEAR STUDY OF THE GLOBAL EDDY INDUCED MATERIAL TRANSPORT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PRODUCING THE MOST RELIABLE ALTIMETRY BASED DIFFUSIVITY ESTIMATES ALONG WITH THE CORRESPONDING MAPS OF THE LOCATION DEPENDENT UNCERTAINTY IN THESE ESTIMATES AND SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE OPTIMAL USE OF RAW ALONG-TRACK DATA FOR THESE ESTIMATES. WE WILL EXTEND OUR PREVIOUS STUDY IN THE NORTH ATLANTIC TO THE GLOBAL DOMAIN AND COMBINE IT WITH A SUITE OF CAREFULLY DESIGNED OBSERVING SYSTEM SIMULATION EXPERIMENTS OSSES. OUR OBJECTIVES ARE TO, 1, EXAMINE THE SENSITIVITY AND ACCURACY OF THE ALTIMETRY BASED EDDY DIFFUSIVITY ESTIMATES TO THE SPATIO TEMPORAL RESOLUTION OF THE UNDERLYING SSH FIELDS, 2, COME UP WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE OPTIMAL PROCESSING APPROACH FOR THE ALONGTRACK SSH MEASUREMENTS THAT YIELDS THE MOST RELIABLE ESTIMATES OF THE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES, AND 3, SYSTEMATICALLY DESCRIBE THE GLOBAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE EDDY DIFFUSIVITIES ALONG WITH THEIR UNCERTAINTY LEVELS, SPATIAL INHOMOGENEITIES, ANISOTROPIC PROPERTIES, DEPENDENCE ON LARGE-SCALE PARAMETERS, AND IMPORTANCE OF MOTIONS NOT RESOLVED BY ALTIMETRY. THIS STUDY DIRECTLY ADDRESSES ONE OF THE RESEARCH THEMES IN THE PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHY PROGRAM BY CONTRIBUTING TO THE INTERPRETATION OF THE OCEAN MESOSCALE CIRCULATION USING SATELLITE DATA. THE RESULTS ARE EXPECTED TO ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SIGNIFICANCE OF EDDY TRANSPORT OF SUCH CLIMATICALLY IMPORTANT QUANTITIES AS HEAT AND CARBON AND ARE, THEREFORE, HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE U.S. CLIVAR OBJECTIVE TO, TO DESCRIBE AND UNDERSTAND THE PHYSICAL PROCESSES RESPONSIBLE FOR CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND PREDICTABILITY, THROUGH THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF OBSERVATIONS. THE RESULTS WILL ALSO HAVE IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR VALIDATION AND FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF CLIMATE MODELS THAT EITHER PARAMETERIZE OR PARTIALLY RESOLVE MESOSCALE EDDIES, IN DIRECT RELEVANCE TO ANOTHER CLIVAR OBJECTIVE TO, TO EXTEND THE RANGE AND ACCURACY OF SEASONAL TO INTERANNUAL CLIMATE PREDICTION THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF GLOBAL COUPLED PREDICTIVE MODELS.

doc.ContractDescription: HEALTH OF THE MUSCULOSKELETAL SYSTEM DEPENDS ON EXPOSURE TO MECHANICAL LOADING. REMOVAL OR REDUCTION OF MECHANICAL LOADING PRECIPITATES MUSCLE ATROPHY AND BONE LOSS. THUS, DESPITE RIGOROUS EXERCISE PROTOCOLS AND OTHER COUNTERMEASURES, MUSCLE ATROPHY AND BONE LOSS ARE STILL VIRTUALLY INEVITABLE CONSEQUENCES OF SPACEFLIGHT. ONE APPROACH FOR AMELIORATING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THESE UNTOWARD CONSEQUENCES OF SPACE TRAVEL IS BY THE INDUCTION OF ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY DURING SPACEFLIGHT VIA CENTRIFUGATION. THE STRENGTH OF THE ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY DEPENDS BOTH ON THE SPEED OF ROTATION AND DIAMETER OF THE SHIP. WHILE IT IS POSSIBLE TO ACHIEVE CENTRIFUGAL FORCE EQUIVALENT 1.0G, IT IS ALSO POSSIBLE THAT LOWER LEVELS OF FORCE MAY ALSO BE EFFECTIVE FOR PREVENTING MUSCLE ATROPHY AND IRREVERSIBLE BONE LOSS. IN THIS STUDY, WE PROPOSE TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL EFFECTIVENESS OF ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY FOR THE PREVENTION OF MUSCLE ATROPHY AND WEAKNESS AND BONE LOSS BY STUDYING RATS USING AN INNOVATIVE SYSTEM FOR PARTIAL UNLOADING THAT HAS BEEN DEVELOPED PREVIOUSLY FOR MICE BY MEMBERS OF OUR TEAM. WE WILL STUDY THE MUSCULOSKELETAL RESPONSE OF ADULT MALE RATS (N=L 4 I GROUP) FOLLOWING EXPOSURE TO DIFFERENT DEGREES OF UNLOADING REPRESENTING 0.2G, 0.4G, AND 0. 7G AS WELL AS FULLY LOADED ANIMALS FOR 1, 2 AND 4 WEEKS. WE WILL STUDY THE IMPACT OF THIS PARTIAL GRAVITY ANALOG ENVIRONMENT ON MUSCLE AND BONE STMCTURE AND FUNCTION, INCLUDING PERFORMING HISTOLOGICAL ANALYSES, IN SITU FORCE MEASUREMENT OF MUSCLE CONTRACTION, AS WELL AS MEASUREMENT OF BONE MASS, MICROARCHITECTURE AND STRENGTH. IN ADDITION, WE WILL PERFORM BOTH SEROLOGICAL AND TISSUE MOLECULAR ANALYSES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE MECHANISMS AND TIME COURSE OF DEVELOPMENT OF THESE CHANGES AT DIFFERENT DEGREES OF UNLOADING. THIS WORK WILL ALSO ALLOW US TO MORE EFFECTIVELY UNDERSTAND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE DEVELOPMENT OF MUSCLE ATROPHY AND WEAKNESS AND BONE DETERIORATION AT VARYING LEVELS OF ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY. AT THE CONCLUSION OF THIS STUDY, WE WILL HAVE DEFINED THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF PARTIAL ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY FOR PREVENTION OF MUSCULOSKELETAL DYSFUNCTION AND DETERIORATION. THIS WORK WILL INFORM THE FUTURE APPLICATION OF ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY IN HUMAN RESEARCH AND SPACE EXPLORATION.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO 1) COMPILE A HYPERSPECTRAL RRS-IOPS DATASET FROM FIELD MEASUREMENTS; 2) IMPROVE THE ESTIMATION OF SSIOP FROM OCEAN COLOR; 3) REVISE THE QAA AND HOPE (A HYPERSPECTRAL OPTIMIZATION ALGORITHM) TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE HYPERSPECTRAL AND UV MEASUREMENTS OFFERED BY PACE, WITH A GOAL TO EXPAND THE CURRENT IOP PRODUCTS TO INCLUDE INFORMATION BEYOND CHLOROPHYLL-A (E.G., THE ABSORPTION COEFFICIENTS OF CHLOROPHYLL-B,-C, AND PHYCOCYANIN); AND 4) TEST AND EVALUATE THESE SEMIANALYTICAL ALGORITHMS WITH HICO MEASUREMENTS. OUTCOMES FROM THIS EFFORT WILL BE FOURFOLD: 1) A HYPERSPECTRAL RRS-IOPS DATASET WITH CLOSURE FOR THE COMMUNITY TO USE, 2) IMPROVED ESTIMATION OF SSIOP FROM OCEAN COLOR TO BENEFIT ALL SEMI-ANALYTICAL ALGORITHMS, 3) REVISED QAA AND HOPE TO DERIVE HYPERSPECTRAL IOP PRODUCTS, AND 4) EXPERIENCE WITH HICO IN PROCESSING AND STORING HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGE PRODUCTS. THESE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE DESIRED TOOLS AND KNOWLEDGE FOR PROCESSING HYPERSPECTRAL MEASUREMENTS BY PACE, AND CONTRIBUTE TO "CONSENSUS AND COMMUNITYENDORSED PATHS FORWARD FOR THE PACE SENSOR(S)".

doc.ContractDescription: OBJECTIVE: TO GENERATE, THEN ARCHIVE AT THE PDS, VERTICAL PROFILES OF IONOSPHERIC ELECTRON DENSITY AT TITAN AND SATURN FROM ARCHIVED LOW-LEVEL CASSINI RADIO OCCULTATION DATA. WE PROPOSE TO ACQUIRE TIME SERIES OF RECEIVED RADIO SIGNAL PROPERTIES DURING OCCULTATIONS AT TITAN AND SATURN FROM THE PDS, AND TO USE EXISTING SOFTWARE TO GENERATE VERTICAL PROFILES OF IONOSPHERIC ELECTRON DENSITY AT TITAN AND SATURN. THE PROPOSAL PRESENTS PRELIMINARY ELECTRON DENSITY PROFILES AT TITAN AND AT SATURN THAT WE HAVE DERIVED FROM ARCHIVED PDS DATA. THE SOFTWARE WILL REQUIRE SOME MODIFICATION FOR THE SATURN CASE DUE TO THE PLANET'S NON-SPHERICAL, OBLATE SHAPE, AND THE PROPOSAL DEMONSTRATES A METHOD FOR SOLVING THIS PROBLEM. NEUTRAL PROFILES WILL NOT BE DERIVED, SINCE IT IS MUCH MORE COMPLICATED TO DERIVE THEM FROM TIME SERIES OF RECEIVED FREQUENCIES THAN IT IS TO DERIVE THE ELECTRON DENSITY PROFILES.
